User Input and Print Statements

For user input, interactive applications often require user input for customization, personalization, and dynamic responses. In Java, the 'Scanner' class is commonly used for reading input from various sources. We can import the 'Scanner' class by using import java.util.Scanner; and you can create the 'Scanner' object with Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);. Common methods for reading data are: 'nextLine()': Reads an entire line of text, 'nextInt()': Reads an integer, 'nextDouble()': Reads a double, 'next()': Reads the next word, 'nextBoolean()': Reads a boolean value. To close up the scanner you would use scanner.close();. Print statements are essential for debugging, displaying information to the user and logging. Java has several methods for printing which include: 'print()', and 'printf()'. 'System.out.print()' prints text without a newline at the end, 'System.out.println()' prints text with a newline at the end, and 'System.out.printf()' prints formatted text using format specifiers.


Syntax and Usage

System.out.print(): System.out.print(data)

  • Example: System.out.print("Hello World!");

System.out.println(): System.out.println(data)

  • Example: System.out.println("Hello World!");

System.out.printf(): System.out.printf(format, arguments)

  • Format Specifiers: '%d' for integers, '%f' for floating-point numbers, '%s' for strings, '%c' for characters, and '%b' for booleans.
  • Example: System.out.printf("Hello, %s!", "World");

In-depth examples of User Input

Reading a String

  • Example: 
                import java.util.Scanner;

            public class ReadString {
                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
                    System.out.print("Enter your favorite fruit: ");
                    String fruit = scanner.nextLine();
                    System.out.println("Youre favorite fruit is " + fruit);
                    scanner.close(); 
                    // Output: [Enter your favorite fruit: Apple
                                Your favorite fruit is Apple]
                }
            }

Reading a Character

  • Example: 
                import java.util.Scanner;

            public class ReadCharacter {
                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
                    System.out.print("Enter a character: ");
                    char character = scanner.next().charAt(0);
                    System.out.println("You entered: " + character);
                    scanner.close();
                    // Output: [Enter a character: A 
                                You entered: A]
                }
            }

In-depth examples of Print Statements

Printing a String

  • Example: 
                public class PrintString {
                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    System.out.println("Hello, World!"); // Output: [Hello, World!]
                }
            }

Printing an Integer

  • Example: 
                public class PrintInteger {
                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    int number = 42;
                    System.out.println("The number is: " + number); // Output: [The number is: 42]
                }
            }

Using 'printf' for Formatted Output

  • Example: 
                public class PrintFormatted {
                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    String name = "Bob";
                    int age = 25;
                    double salary = 45000.50;
                    System.out.printf("Name: %s, Age: %d, Salary: $%.2f\n", name, age, salary); // Output: [Name: Bob, Age: 25, Salary: $45000.50]
                }
            }
